title: Perpetual Problems
description: Explore how you navigate ongoing differences that may never fully resolve.

questions.text: My view on ongoing differences that keep coming up is...
choices: They're normalâ€”all couples have them
They're frustrating but manageable
They worry me about our compatibility
They can be opportunities for growth

therapeutic.rationale: Views on perpetual problems affect how you cope. Normalizers accept them; frustrated-but-managing types cope; worry-types question the relationship; growth-seers find meaning. Gottman found 69% of couple conflicts are perpetual.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The normalizer may not understand the worrier's concern; the worrier may not accept that some issues never resolve. Share your views.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared view creates aligned expectations about ongoing differences.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about issues that keep coming up? What would help you cope better?

questions.text: When we keep having the same argument, I tend to...
choices: Get frustrated that it's not resolved
Look for new approaches to discuss it
Accept that we see things differently here
Wonder what's really underneath the issue

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to recurring conflicts vary. Frustration-feelers want resolution; new-approach seekers try different tactics; accepters make peace with difference; underneath-lookers seek root causes. All can be adaptive responses.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different responses can complement. The accepter can help the frustrated partner find peace; the new-approach seeker can help the accepter stay engaged.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response creates aligned approach to recurring conflicts.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond to recurring conflicts? Is it working?

questions.text: I believe that ongoing differences in a relationship...
choices: Don't have to mean the relationship is bad
Require active management and dialogue
Reveal fundamental values or personality
Can either divide or deepen us

therapeutic.rationale: Beliefs about what perpetual problems mean vary. Not-bad believers separate issue from relationship; active-managers see work needed; revealer-types see core differences; divide-or-deepen types see choice. These beliefs shape response.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different beliefs may cause different worry levels. The not-bad believer may seem dismissive to the revealer-type. Share what ongoing differences mean to you.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared meaning creates aligned understanding of what ongoing differences signify.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do ongoing differences mean about your relationship? What do you make of them?

questions.text: The key to living with ongoing differences is...
choices: Finding humor and lightness about them
Respecting the valid reasons behind each view
Creating workarounds that honor both people
Accepting each other fully, differences included

therapeutic.rationale: Coping strategies for perpetual problems vary. Humor-finders lighten; respect-givers honor; workaround-creators problem-solve; accepters embrace. All can help couples live with differences that won't resolve.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different coping strategies can all help. Use multiple approaches together.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared coping strategy creates aligned approach to managing ongoing differences.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you live with differences that won't resolve? What would help more?

questions.text: What I most want my partner to understand about our ongoing differences is...
choices: They don't change how I feel about us
I'm still committed to working on them
I accept and love them despite our differences
We're more alike than different

therapeutic.rationale: Messages about ongoing differences reveal priorities. Unchanged-feeling types prioritize relationship over issues; commitment-expressers show dedication; acceptance-givers show love; similarity-focusers emphasize common ground. Hearing this message can reassure.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different messages can all be shared. Your partner may need to hear several of these.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared message means you both want your partner to know the same thing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you most want your partner to understand about your ongoing differences?
